F ifteentlz Problem

If from a square I subtract four of its roots and then take one-third of the remainder, finding this equal to four of the soors, the square will be 256.¹

Explanation. Since one-third of the remainder is equal to four roots, you know that the remainder itself will equal 12 roots. T herefore add this to the four, giving 16 roots. This (16) is the root of the square.

S ixteentlz Problem

From a square I subtract three of its roots and multiply the remainder by itself 3 the sum total of this multiplicatiori equals the square.2

Explanation. It is evident that the remainder is equal to the root, which amounts to four. The square is 16.
